headline.main: Suffolk's Unusual Legislature: Incubator or Just a Hothouse?

docs.section_name: Front Page; New York and Region

byline.original: By ERIC SCHMITT, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: For nearly two decades, the Suffolk County Legislature has been an incubator of ideas ranging from bottle deposits to smoking bans. Sometimes first, sometimes far out, it has also considered less-successful proposals, such as one to establish a county navy.

headline.main: Surgeon General Asserts Smoking Is an Addiction

byline.original: By MARTIN TOLCHIN, Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: The Surgeon General of the United States warned today that nicotine was as addictive as heroin and cocaine and recommended the licensing of those who sell tobacco products and tougher laws prohibiting their sale to minors.
docs.snippet: LEAD: The Surgeon General of the United States warned today that nicotine was as addictive as heroin and cocaine and recommended the licensing of those who sell tobacco products and tougher laws prohibiting their sale to minors.

byline.original: By Morris Dickstein; Morris Dickstein first wrote about the Columbia University uprising in his book ''Gates of Eden: American Culture in the Sixties,'' which will appear in a new edition from Penguin Books next year. He teaches English at Queens College

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: IN MANY WAYS IT LOOKED LIKE A TYPICAL college reunion. People who hadn't seen each other in 20 years were embracing, trading stories of their lives, peering at snapshots of their children - or at the children themselves, for there were lots of kids along: this was a generation that had its children late.

byline.original: By John Tierney; John Tierney is a writer living in New York

docs.lead_paragraph: LEAD: LAST OCT. 19, A DAY THAT ONLY A stress researcher could savor, a 48-year-old stockbroker named Gianni Fidanza happened to be wearing a little metal box on his waist when he went to his Park Avenue office. It was wired to a cuff on his arm that measured his blood pressure and pulse every 15 minutes.
